text:
Immigration – Landeshauptstadt München search close search Enter search term start search Menu close menu navigation language City Hall Events Culture, Leisure Restaurants Shopping Sights Tourism Hotels Business Living Transportation Current language: English Deutsch Français Italiano Русский العربية 中文 Startseite City of Munich Immigration City of Munich Information for Immigrants You want to visit, work, study, settle or seek asylum in Munich? Here's all you need to know. Topics and life situations Asylum Have you fled to Germany? Information and services relating to asylum applications and residence permits. Services and Regulations Entry visa Entry visa for academic/doctoral studies, German language courses, scientific activities and scholarships Formal Obligation Visa applicants often have to submit a formal obligation at the German embassy or consulate abroad. Residence Registration When moving to Munich to take up permanent residence, you must register your address within two weeks of your arrival. Registration for EU Citizens EU citizens and citizens of Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein do not need a visa to enter Germany and do not need to apply for a residence permit. Working Permit Blue Card, permit for self-employed work or for highly qualified persons: All you need to know if you want to come to work in Munich. Au Pair to Student How can you change your legal residence status from being an au pair to being a student? Prerequisites, documents and application. Absences Abroad Longer absences should always be communicated to the Foreigners Office to find out, how or if they might affect your re-entry. Changing Studies Changing your course of study, moving to a different university: What foreign students have to consider concerning their residence permit. Study and Research in Munich What's required to study or do research in Munich? Infos on recognition of qualifications, academic and student life, research options and contacts. Labor Market Access The Munich Employment and Qualification Program (MBQ) offers migrants and refugees a broad range of free services as well as access to the labor market. Munich Employment and Qualification The MBQ is the City of Munich’s labor market program. Aim is to professionally, socially integrate people into the labor market, acquire and retain skilled workers. Coming Home The Coming Home project supports refugees, asylum seekers and third-country nationals obliged to depart to reintegrate in their home countries. INTEGREAT App Munich How can I get an apartment? Are there language courses available? Where can I turn to when I’m sick? Find answers in the multilingual app INTEGREAT for new immigrants in Munich. Discover the app Guides and Information This is a carousel with rotating cards. Use the previous and next buttons to
                    navigate, and Enter to activate cards. Vorheriger Slide Information on Brexit The United Kingdom left the European Union on January  31st, 2020. All information concerning Brexit – regulary updated. Foreign Students Registration, bank account, residence permit: A step-by-step-guide for international students arriving in Munich. Munich Educational Portfolio The Munich Educational Portfolio is a folder designed for refugees and immigrants 16 years of age or older. Study and Research in Munich What's required to study or do research in Munich? Infos on recognition of qualifications, academic and student life, research options and contacts. summary:
Immigration information for visitors, workers, students, and asylum seekers in Munich:

- Asylum: Information and services for those who have fled to Germany.
- Entry visa: Requirements and regulations for various types of entry visas.
- Formal obligation: Information on formal obligations for visa applicants.
- Residence registration: Registration requirements for permanent residents.
- EU citizens: No visa or residence permit required for EU citizens and citizens of Norway, Iceland, and Liechtenstein.
- Working permit: Information on Blue Cards, self-employed work permits, and highly qualified work permits.
- Au pair to student: Changing residence status from au pair to student.
- Absences abroad: Communication requirements for longer absences.
- Changing studies: Requirements for changing courses of study or universities.
- Study and research: Information on studying or researching in Munich, including recognition of qualifications and research options.
- Labor market access: The Munich Employment and Qualification Program (MBQ) for migrants and refugees.
- Coming Home: A project supporting refugees, asylum seekers, and third-country nationals.
- INTEGREAT App: A multilingual app for new immigrants in Munich, providing answers to various questions.
- Guides and information: A carousel with rotating cards offering information on various topics.
- Brexit: Regularly updated information on the UK's departure from the EU.
- Foreign students: Registration, bank account, and residence permit requirements for international students.
- Munich Educational Portfolio: A folder for refugees and immigrants 16 years of age or older.
- Childcare and education: Information on international schools and kindergartens.
- International professionals: Services for professionals.
- Social media: Follow the City of Munich on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and YouTube.
- Newsletter: The Landeshauptstadt München newsletter.
- City plan: The city plan.
- Public transportation: The public transportation schedule.
- Culture: Information on culture and tourism.
- Tourism: Information on tourism.
- M-Strom: Information on the M-Strom
